title: Scaling Agentic Workflows with E2B Sandboxes and Orchestration
summary: This workflow demonstrates how to scale AI engineering by moving from single-agent prompting to multi-agent orchestration using E2B Sandboxes. It addresses real-world feedback by deploying parallel agent forks to independently experiment, code, and generate Pull Requests, utilizing the 'Best of N' pattern to select optimal solutions.

steps.action: Initialize Orchestrator and Prompt Engineer agents in separate terminals
steps.reasoning: Establishes a dual-agent control plane: one for managing workflow execution (Orchestrator) and one for refining inputs (Prompt Engineer).

steps.action: Prime the Orchestrator Agent with specific context
steps.reasoning: Configures the main agent with the necessary context and command structures to manage downstream sandbox environments effectively.

steps.action: Transform raw feedback into structured prompts using the AGP template
steps.reasoning: Converts unstructured user feedback (Reddit comments) into precise, actionable instructions for front-end coding agents.

steps.action: Launch parallel agent forks in isolated sandboxes via CLI
steps.reasoning: Executes the 'Best of N' pattern by running multiple instances of the agent simultaneously in isolated environments to generate diverse solutions.

steps.action: Monitor concurrent sandbox execution and resource usage
steps.reasoning: Provides observability into the autonomous agents' status, ensuring they have adequate CPU/Memory to complete tasks.

steps.action: Verify agent outputs via logs and generated public URLs
steps.reasoning: Validates the success of autonomous tasks by inspecting the build logs and the live preview of the code changes.

steps.action: Review and select the best Pull Requests
steps.reasoning: Finalizes the workflow by selecting the optimal implementation from the parallel experiments (Best of N) to merge into the main codebase.

steps.action: Inspect system prompts and MCP tool configurations
steps.reasoning: Demonstrates the underlying engineering required to define agent permissions, tools, and environment variables within the sandbox.

key_takeaways: Agent Sandboxes (E2B) provide secure, isolated microVMs that allow agents to execute code and use tools without risking the host system.
The 'Agentic Path' evolves from single-agent prompting to Orchestrator-level workflows where one agent manages multiple sub-agents.
The 'Best of N' pattern mitigates LLM non-determinism by running parallel agents and selecting the superior result.
Scaling compute scales impact: Sandboxes allow for massive parallelization of engineering tasks, treating agents as disposable, high-agency resources.
